summary: NSDV belongs to genus Nairovirus of the family Bunyaviridae. it causes severe disease characterised by fever and haemorrhagic gastroenteritis in sheep and goats with a mortality rate up to 90% in a susceptible population [1], [2]. NSDV is closely related to a human pathogen, Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV), which causes viral haemorrhagic gastroenteritis CCHFV is the second most widespread of the arboviruses pathogenic to humans. the disease is similar to that caused in sheep and goats by NSDV infection [2], [29]. NSDV may act as a suitable model to study haemorrhagic nairoviruses. newly synthesised virions bud into the Golgi and are transported to the plasma membrane. the virions exit the infected cell after fusion of the carrier vesicle with the plasma membrane. nairoviruses would be expected to affect the secretory pathway. cells were cultured in Glasgow Modified Eagle's Medium (GMEM) containing 10% foetal calf serum (FCS), penicillin (100 U/ml), streptomycin sulphate (100 mg/ml), 2 mM L-glutamine and 5% tryptose phosphate broth.
